stories.title: Meaningful Work: What Leaders Can Learn from NASA and the Space Race (2017)

stories.text:
I'd like to equip my kid with a watch that can be used as a phone.

I found many different model, but they all require an app to operate.

So I am wondering if the HN community could help me find if there a model that is more "hackable"?

For example, for GPS tracking, I'd like to be able to specify an URL and have the phone do a POST request on it every few minutes or so.

I only need phone (audio only) and GPS tracking. And I want to use my linux workstation to configure it (like updating configuration file or the like).
stories.title: Ask HN: Hackable Phone Watch for Kid without app
In search of the largest data center
Whirlpool to Shutdown as Supply Chain Continues Disruption

stories.text:
In today's business world, there are some markets that are dominated by one "big bro", two or sometimes even three players which make these markets extremely hard to penetrate and compete against for newcomers.

Can you give an example (or more) while, if possible, citing their common weak point(s) and how a newcomer can benefit from this and get in?

Below are may tries:

Monopoly: Search Engine - Google

Weaknesses: Lack of privacy, SEO clickbaits

Duopoly: Mobile App Market - AppStore, PlayStore

Weakness: Forcing cutting 30% revenue from developers

Triopoly: Cloud Providers - AWS, Azure and GCP
stories.title: Cite some examples of Monopoly, Duopoly or Triopoly? How a newcomer can get in?
